Author: cromulent
Content:
I wouldn't be surprised if wristwatches break Norvig's law soon.

I can't find any statistics, but it appears to me they had over 50% penetration in the 80's, have dropped well below that, but are coming back (and so might double).

Author: codex
Content: A published paper vs a mailing list post, is that the way of it?  From what I've seen, PSNR is the most widely used codec scoring method, and most of the PSNR complaining comes from losing codecs, but with never any rebuttal data.  It's not perfect but does correlate with human visual perception.

Author: bradleyland
Content: It's not immediately obvious why this is a security issue, and this doesn't result in any disclosures or privilege escalation, but this is still a security issue, because it means the values aren't being validated for consistency when saved. It is possible that the authors of the code saw it and let it pass because there doesn't appear to be a direct vulnerability here, but any time you allow a user to manipulate your app in to an internally inconsistent state, it's a security failure. Other code that depends on consistent internal state may break in unexpected ways.

Author: robrenaud
Content:
Double counting is not allowed by the definition. From wikipedia. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_penetration

> It is a measure of brand or category popularity. It is defined as the number of people who buy a specific brand or a category of goods at least once in a given period
Created: divided by the size of the relevant market population."

Author: burntsushi
Content:
Armin (the OP) wrote a great guide for exactly that.[1] I used it to successfully write code that was compatible for both 2 and 3.

I am, however, sympathetic to the OP here. By far, the most trouble I had writing 2/3 compatible code was the string handling. It was pretty painful.

[1] - http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2013/5/21/porting-to-python-3-redux/"
